awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Scalable Manufacturing of Two-dimensional Atomic Layer Materials for Energy-efficient Electronic Devices via Selective-area Atomic Layer Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) grant supports research in the scalable manufacturing of atomically-thin semiconducting materials for high performance, energy-efficient electronic devices. The project studies selective-area or seeded atomic layer deposition, a manufacturing technique used to deposit materials with high precision and uniformity. This award establishes a new mode of manufacturing for low temperature fabrication of high quality two-dimensional nanomaterials, which allows early adoption of these new materials into the semiconductor industry and supports continued improvements in electronic device performance, including information storage capacity and computational power, all while lowering the energy demands of these devices. These materials are also promising components of quantum information processing devices, thus aligning well with NSF's Quantum Leap effort. The results of this research benefits society and the national economy through the advancement of innovative solutions to the nation's increasing energy and computational demands. Additionally, this research advances engineering knowledge and trains the next generation of scientists and engineers in advanced manufacturing and prepare them for careers in industry. Through partnership with Boise State's Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Diversity and Inclusion Initiative, the research and outreach activities of this award expands participation for underrepresented groups, directly supporting the aims of the NSF INCLUDES program. 

Semiconducting two-dimensional (2D) atomic layer materials, such as transition metal dichalcogenides, offer large direct band gaps, high on-off ratios, and high room temperature mobilities. The key challenge to deploying these materials in memory and logic devices is the ability to synthesize them in their 2D form at device compatible temperatures with minimal substrate interaction, control over the number of layers, and control over the chemical composition for heterostructure formation and doping. Selective-area atomic layer deposition (ALD), in a unique van der Waals growth mode, can overcome the current limitations for synthesis of the 2D nanomaterials. Typically, 2D materials are grown by chemical vapor deposition at high temperatures, which is not suitable for high aspect-ratio structures. Low temperature ALD produces amorphous films, which requires high temperature annealing to generate the desired microstructure, which is not suitable for some semiconductor devices. This research is to provide the knowledge necessary to synthesize crystalline 2D atomic layer materials at backend-compatible low temperatures through selective-area or seeded ALD with van der Waals bonding to the underlying substrate. The research team employs in situ and ex situ experimentation combined with first-principles computation to understand the chemical reactions critical to both promoting and inhibiting the nucleation and growth of 2D materials on engineered surfaces for high volume semiconductor device manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to advance the scalable manufacturing of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) through fundamental research. 2D materials, which can be as thin as a single atom, hold great potential to improve performance in critical technologies from semiconductor microelectronics to energy harvesting and storage. However, methods to make these materials at high volumes and with sufficient quality for integration into commercial processes have not been established.

To advance 2D materials toward industry adoption, the research in this project focused on gaining the fundamental knowledge, through experiment and computation, of the chemical reactions used to make these materials in commercial processes, such as atomic layer deposition (ALD) and atomic layer etching (ALE), which are used by leading semiconductor companies for all logic and memory devices made today. Through our work, we identified key chemical factors that can be used to control exactly where the 2D materials are deposited (known as area-selective deposition), which allows industry to avoid costly photolithography steps and reduce consumption of toxic and harmful chemicals, such as PFAS compounds. Additionally, this project discovered two ways to produce 2D TMDCs: a low-temperature process for direct crystalline materials and a high-temperature process with superior conformality to complex surface structures. More work is needed to control these processes and validate performance of the 2D materials at commercial scale, but the processes established by this project provide clear pathways to quickly establish their viability in high volume manufacturing. Based on the results obtained through this project, three new research projects have been started, each with strong input from industry partners, which illustrates the priority placed on realizing these materials through industrial manufacturing processes.

2D TMDCs will enable energy-efficient microelectronic devices through improvements to conventional logic and memory device power requirements, as well as through new low-power devices, such as neuromorphic memory-transistors. Enabling these low power devices is essential for reducing the microelectronic energy consumption footprint of data centers and energy intensive computing centers. The integrated education activities of this project provided opportunities for 11 graduate students, 12 undergraduate students, and 4 high school students to participate in research on state-of-the-art advanced manufacturing of novel materials. These students published 4 publications and presented 15 talks and posters at international conferences and numerous posters at regional conferences. The results of this project have also been presented through invited talks at international conferences.

To meet the challenging requirements for characterization of 2D materials, a new course in scanning probe microscopy (SPM) was created and offered to graduate and senior undergraduate students. Eighth grade elementary school students were also introduced to SPM surface characterization through annual visits to Boise State's SPM research labs. These visits help to generate excitement in materials research at an early age.


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Elton Graugnard
